skill.name: benchling-integration
skill.description: Benchling R&D platform integration. Access registry (DNA, proteins), inventory, ELN entries, workflows via API, build Benchling Apps, query Data Warehouse, for lab data management automation.
skill.summary: Integrate with Benchling R&D platform for biological data management, sequence registry, inventory tracking, and lab notebook automation.
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: This skill consists exclusively of documentation files for the Benchling R&D platform API. Static analysis flagged 455 patterns in markdown files, but all findings are FALSE POSITIVES. The scanner detected markdown code formatting (backticks), example URLs, and placeholder credentials in documentation - not actual executable code with security implications.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [MEDIUM] external_commands: Ruby/shell backtick execution (336 locations across .md files)
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: The scanner detected backtick characters in markdown documentation, which are used for code formatting syntax, not Ruby/shell command execution. All instances are in code example blocks demonstrating legitimate Benchling SDK usage patterns.
The flagged URLs are example placeholders like 'https://your-tenant.benchling.com' in documentation showing users how to format tenant URLs. These are not actual hardcoded sensitive endpoints.

The flagged 'secrets' are placeholder examples like 'your_api_key_here' and 'your_client_secret' in documentation. These are instructional examples showing proper credential handling patterns, not actual exposed credentials.

Scanner flagged text mentioning cryptographic algorithms in documentation. The skill discusses HTTPS for API communication and standard OAuth flows, but contains no actual weak cryptographic implementations.
Scanner misinterpreted documentation about API endpoints and network configuration as reconnaissance patterns. These are legitimate API reference docs showing standard HTTP endpoints.
Scanner flagged a mention of import() in documentation example showing Python import syntax. This is standard documentation for module imports, not dynamic code execution.
Scanner flagged a code example showing CSV export pattern using standard Python file operations. Documentation example only, no actual file operations executed.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [CRITICAL] obfuscation: DANGEROUS COMBINATION: Code execution + Network + Credential access
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: This heuristic flagged documentation examples showing API usage. The 'code execution' is documentation formatting, 'network' are example URLs, 'credentials' are placeholders. No actual malicious code exists - skill is documentation only.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [HIGH] obfuscation: SUSPICIOUS COMBINATION: Filesystem + Credentials + Network
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Similar to above - scanner combined documentation patterns about file operations, credential handling, and API URLs. All are legitimate documentation examples for Benchling integration patterns.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [HIGH] sensitive: Environment file access, Certificate/key files
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Documentation mentions best practices for storing credentials securely and using environment variables. These are security recommendations, not actual file access or certificate handling code.

content.value_statement: Automate laboratory workflows and manage biological data by integrating with the Benchling R&D platform. Access DNA sequences, protein data, inventory, and electronic lab notebooks through the Python SDK or REST API.
actual_capabilities: Authenticate with Benchling using API keys or OAuth for secure access
Create, read, update, and archive DNA, RNA, and protein sequences
Manage laboratory inventory including containers, boxes, and locations
Create and query electronic lab notebook entries and protocols
Automate workflow tasks and monitor task progress asynchronously
Query the Data Warehouse using SQL for analytics and reporting
limitations: Requires an active Benchling account with API access enabled
Does not include the actual Benchling SDK - users must install it separately
Rate limits and permissions are determined by the Benchling tenant configuration
No offline functionality - requires continuous API connectivity

use_cases.title: Automate Sequence Registration
use_cases.description: Bulk import DNA and protein sequences from FASTA files directly into the Benchling registry with proper naming and custom fields.

use_cases.title: Inventory Tracking
use_cases.description: Monitor sample locations, track container transfers, and audit inventory changes across freezer locations and storage units.

use_cases.title: Research Analytics
use_cases.description: Export experimental data from the Data Warehouse for compliance reporting and integration with external BI tools.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Connection
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to authenticate with Benchling using an API key and create a connection to my tenant.

prompt_templates.title: Sequence Operations
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I create a new DNA sequence, register it in the registry, and link it to a notebook entry?

prompt_templates.title: Inventory Management
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a workflow to transfer containers between locations and track the movement history.

prompt_templates.title: Automation Script
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a script to find all sequences with a specific schema and export their names, bases, and creation dates to CSV.

output_examples.input: How do I set up authentication with Benchling using environment variables?
output: Use os.environ to retrieve credentials from environment variables for secure authentication.
Recommended approach: Store your API key in BENCHLING_API_KEY and tenant URL in BENCHLING_TENANT_URL.
This keeps credentials out of your source code and supports secure deployment practices.

best_practices: Store API credentials in environment variables or secret managers, never hardcode them in scripts
Use HTTPS for all API connections - Benchling requires secure communication
Implement proper error handling with retry logic for rate limits and transient failures
anti_patterns: Do not commit API keys or credentials to version control systems
Avoid making requests without checking rate limits or implementing backoff strategies
Do not hardcode tenant URLs - use configuration files or environment variables instead

faq.question: How do I get my Benchling API credentials?
faq.answer: Log into Benchling, go to Profile Settings, and generate an API key. Store it securely as it is shown only once.

faq.question: What Python version is required?
faq.answer: The Benchling SDK requires Python 3.7 or higher. Check your version with python --version.

faq.question: Can I use this skill offline?
faq.answer: No, this skill requires an active internet connection to communicate with the Benchling API.

faq.question: How do I handle rate limits?
faq.answer: The SDK automatically retries on 429 errors with exponential backoff. Configure max_retries in RetryStrategy if needed.

faq.question: What authentication methods are supported?
faq.answer: API Key authentication for scripts and OAuth 2.0 Client Credentials for multi-user applications.

faq.question: Does this skill include the SDK?
faq.answer: No, you must install the benchling-sdk package separately using pip or poetry.
